thread.section_title: News Archive - News, sport and travel archive - Telegraph
thread.title: Daily Telegraph July 9 1915

author: The Telegraph
title: Daily Telegraph July 9 1915
text: * Download the whole paper pdf & view * (30mb) Although it wasn’t the first time recruiting efforts had focused on the capital, the latest efforts to enlist the men of London into the army was the focus of the Telegraph’s attention in today’s paper. Even though Lord Kitchener’s speech to kick-start a three-week push wasn’t until later in the day the report on pages 9 and 10 was given the banner headline on the first of those pages, and London’s efforts so far generated an article on page 10 and a leader on page 8 . As has been seen with some of the pre-war reporting, the Telegraph could be very parochial at times in its coverage of affairs. Also in today’s paper - “Superior Russian forces,” as the Austrians put it, stem the Austro-German tide near Lublin – page 9 - Better news for Austria in the Adriatic, as one of their submarines sinks an Italian cruiser – page 9 - E. Ashmead-Bartlett’s latest Dardanelles despatch is given the headline “Victory in Gallipoli” – page 9 - Our Special Correspondent in Rotterdam is requested by authorities to plead for better packing of parcels to prisoners of war, due to the “deplorable” state of the condition of many passing through the Netherlands – page 10 - Hull is the latest city to see its tram conductors threaten to strike over the employment of women in the role (see March 31 for London and June 17 for Birmingham) but Birmingham has decided to go ahead and employ them in a temporary capacity – page 11 - St Thomas’s Hospital asks for the temporary closure of the public footway between the hospital and the Thames so wounded soldiers can use it, they being unable t do so at present “as there was always a large congregation of women, who were attracted there by the soldiers, and who had caused trouble” – page 11 - The Cycling column seeks to promote touring in Scotland, and reassures readers that the impression “that it rains in Scotland every day, and twice in Sundays” isn’t accurate – page 14 Follow @telegraphnews
